narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Q7b: Dave did a great job as TA. However, I cannot say the same about the communication coaches that the professor hired to help teach the workshop portions of the class. It may have been that I happened to be in sessions with poor instructors, but they rarely gave any kind of feedback, and I had a hard time learning anything from them.Q10: This course offered good basic guidelines for communication, but the guidelines sometimes felt very constricting, as though the creativity of writing and speaking was slowly being eroded.

It was helpful to have opportunity to practice, I wish Id had presentations that I was doing for other classes that I could practice. Perhaps one way to address this would be to have the class at the second half of the semester when students are closer to turning in final projects and presentations for other classes.I appreciate the tips and subject matter is great.The assignments were good. Lots of breadth in the class, but good checklist of ways to improve communication.At times the professor was a bit overbearing. His biases against the ability of some groups to communicate clearly came out frequently and were mildly offensive. Examples include: secretaries, women, F&ES students.That said, his lessons are very clear and lectures were mostly entertaining.

This class should be offered every year. It is incredibly valuable in developing professional skills, and the professor is excellent. I only wish this could be a year-long course or better yet, a program that you opt into after MODS to improve one's communication skills over the course of 2 years.

Question 7: Vance is a great instructor of the material but often made insensitive remarks in lecture which distracted from the material. If gender and cultural generalizations are going to be used as examples, they need better framing (i.e. "Women are often seen as less effectives communicators beginning with their handshakes. Today I will teach you how to avoid that pitfall" instead of "Women are bad at presenting themselves starting with the handshake- so we're going to work on that today."
It would have been really helpful to get feedback on the homework and our performance.
I recommend every F&ES student take the course, ideally as a full-term, 3-credit course.

Question 8. The course is great, but I wish it's a longer class. Many sessions seem very rushed due to the time limitation (we only have 12 hours for the entire class). It would be much more beneficial to students if the class sessions are doubled and we have more time to practice things we learned through lectures.

Q10: I think this is a very valuable course, and everyone should have the opportunity to benefit from it in some way. I consciously used strategies from the course when designing presentations of my research, speaking in front of groups, and running meetings.
quick tips for more effective learning (the blue sheet that william asked us to keep during the class)
Getting a chance to practice communication skills in a way that was recorded and evaluated.
Regardless of the person's communications skills, the communication class really helped people improved. It was amazing to see how everyone from the quiet and timid ot the most verbose improved.
the opportunity to practice

I think this course was extremely well-designed. The in-class group exercises were absolutely invaluable in forcing us out of our comfort zone and opening ourselves up to constructive criticism. Basing the class around practical exercises was extremely effective and ultimately enjoyable (looking back on it, months later).
The clear, practical, and applicable skills taught in the course, and feedback provided in small groups -- particularly from instructors.
Appreciate being able to view own performance on film.
Application of material in a variety of exercises and simulations
My improvement in presentation and communication skills.
The in-class excercizes
Receiving bullet points for how to improve many forms of communication and receiving individual feedback for each style in the lab portion of class. The communications assessment was great.
Thecoursework will help me to be more concise in developing presentations. The course materials offered a great template for writing projects.
The tutors and class exercises

Extremely, extremely useful for any professional! All the skills I learned in this class I will use again on the job. I enjoyed all the video/sound clips the professor used, and appreciated the handouts he passed out each week.
Individual feedback from the professor and peers, plus mandatory practice
Is the application aspect of it. Students get to practice what they have learnt and also video taped to help them look at and critique themselves.
Having the TA videotape my presentations/speeches and receiving candid feedback from peers and instructors.
practice speaking but there could be more time spent on writing but that would not be enough for 6 six week course.
This class was great! Given the small amount of your time that this class requires, it gives a pretty big payoff. It improved my presentation style significantly.

Communication skills are necessary no matter what you are doing professionally, yet we never have formal opportunities to practice and improve these skills. This course offered a forum for practicing, critiquing and improving such skills.
It was very practical and helpful in technically improving my presentation to writing skills.
The active participation. The best way to learn how to communicate is by practicing communications! This course did a great job of this.
This course effectively used in-class exercises and carefully selected readings to teach us how to speak effectively and hold effective meetings.

The best thing about this class is that you get video tapped while you give a presentation. This allows you to see how you are projecting yourself and is very insightful.Additionally - The readings were short but great. The presentations that the instructor gave were also useful. I think practicing and getting feedback on our presentations was also useful.
The course content, Dr. Vence had put together a very nice overview of key skills for the students.The practice sessions are good as well. We got to experience what he meant in his lecture.

The mix of lecture and practice, both inside and outside of class. There were many opportunities to practice skills learned in class!Lectures were short, succinct and direct to the point, with the most important concepts highlighted throughout. This made a 6pm Monday night class not only quite digestible, but enjoyable.
The clear and focused strategies, and good examples given by Dr. Vance.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: the communications coaches. william gave helpful tips by letting us make mistakes first, but the coaches were unhelpful in my experience.

I found the class a worthwhile venue for practicing my public speaking but wish that I would have gotten more guidance and feedback throughout the semester. The design of the class, lecture at the start and the last half of the class for presentations, complicated prepping for presentations because specific tips to incorporate were not given until the first half of the class. Perhaps breaking the class into two nights per week instead, one early in the week for the lecture and then one later in the week for presentation after students have time to prepare.
I think and additional week or two would be useful, there is so much more to cover.
not enough feedback on your assignments

The length of the course is too short. We had a good rhythm going - we were learning a lot, getting settled in our work groups, and then it ended. It seemed like there was no shortage of material that Prof. Vance could have covered, and we certainly would have benefited from the extra time to practice on the issues we identified where we needed to improve.
I would have appreciated feedback on homework and even more constructive criticism from instructors on things like the presentation and networking pitch.
Wish that folks werent always so positive in their criticism and could give more constructive, real feedback.
More time and depth to do the material justice (a 2-3 credit class)
It is too short.
There is a lot of work for a 1-unit class; maybe it could be worth 1.5 or 2

The professor made some highly inappropriate comments about different groups (women, international students, etc). It was very distracting - I chose to stay in the course despite his comments because I wanted to improve my communication skills. However, I'm pretty disappointed that FES allows him to say those kinds of things in class and that I had to hear those comments while taking a class on, of all things, effective communication.
It would be great to receive feedback from each of the instructors or at least everytime and allow more time for feedback in each group.
The instructions for the assignments were a bit unclear at times.
The duration should be extended

Make it a full semester in length instead of just a short course. We had to go through the material very quickly and I would have liked spending more time on each skill we covered. I also didn't feel like a lot of the professional folks he had come in to work with us actually did that much. I was expecting them to give us more feedback/interact with us more.
It would be great if this were made into a full-term course - I could use much more help than 1-credit's worth.

It should be thought as a 3 credit class because being taught as 1 credit for a month forces the Professor to compress lecture materials. If taught for a 3 credit it will be very helpful to students because it is such a wonderful class.
individual feedback on assignments.
It was too short and the course must be extended to 10-12 lectures.
Not much more you can improve upon in a six week course. It would be nice to have additional one on one sessions with professor Vance. (Although this may be difficult with such a large class).
The assignments were quite difficult because we had to first create our own situation which made the assignments more time consuming than necessary for a 1 credit class.
The course is too short! We need more practice and face-to-face time with the coaches.

This course should be expanded into a semester long endeavor. The skills and lessons taught are invaluable, a basic necessity for a professional in any field, but especially for a professional seeking to communicate difficult and often unpalatable ideas, like the ideas of an environmentalist.The course highlights FES's current scant emphasis on the development of a professional demeanor tailored to public policy and other highly interactive fields.

There was never enough time to practice and be critiqued, and occasionally Dr. Vance made bizarre jokes or showed video clips that while not crossing the line to be racist or sexist certainly distracted from his message about communicating.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: the one time i emailed william, he was quick to respond, and helpful.

I was frustrated that I was told that I could not miss even one class but there was at least one class where the instructors/workshop leaders were not present because "they weren't needed" leaving us only working/getting comments from peers. The most feedback I got during the class was from my peers, never directly from the instructor. I never got one on one time from the instructor and comments were never given on assignments that were turned in. The only option for one on one time with the prof was one day at the end of the class during mid terms.
Great!
Some of the instructors in the small groups did not really make any comments on the presentations. Some did though. I feel like the other students we a lot more helpful sometimes.
could have been better
The TA David was very helpful and on top of things.I also appreciate the Dr. Vance's willingness to give feedback and provide additional communication evaluations.
Professor did not always respond to emails, but was very approachable and helpful. TA very responsive and helpful.
Both were very accesible
Great.
Both were very helpful and efficient in their responses to questions.
The instructor.He was very helpful and available.

Both the instructor and TA were very responsive to emails and accommodating when I had issues trying to upload videos to the class website. The professor was extremely knowledgeable, but sometimes came off as a bit pretentious and un-PC (i.e. during the first class lecture he talked about how certain races of people are always late, and how FES secretaries are not very professional). Other than that he was fantastic though.
Excellent opportunity with the office hours work session
Very helpful
The Prof. offered a post-class private consulting session with all interested students. I took advantage of this offer, and it was very helpful.
I had no great sense of availability to either the instructor or the TA
The professor was available and contacted him directly.
TA was very helpful!
Great!
The instructor was helpful in providing guidance and follow up.
they are good, but it would be great if we can have one-on-one sessions with them after class.
Dave was always willing to answer questions, jolly and charming as usual, always considerate.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: the course was not what i thought it would be, but i found it helpful for any person who has to write or say anything for or to other people.
It's a professional skill, something that I think FES could emphasize more.
This course fits into everyone's overall program because everybody needs to be an effective communicator. I seriously believe that this should be a required course for all FES students.

This is an excellent course for anyone who is ever going to need to speak or write in order communicate -- in other words, everyone. It was exactly what I expected from a Professional Skills class in terms of efficiently presenting very useful and practical information that I can immediately incorporate into my work. While the environmental aspect of the course is a bit of an add-on and simply provides a common subject matter, the communication skills part of it will be highly relevant to my career.
It's an excellent fit for anyone who needs practice and tips on professional communication.
We all need to graduate with good communication skills. Most scientists are poor communicators. This class is invaluable.

Every student at a professional school should be required to take this course. No matter you professional background or lack thereof, you need to know how to write and present more clearly and concisely.

This course is important for people who will be interacting with many different groups (industry, communities, government, etc) and learning how to target your message to different people. It was great to be able to practice public speaking skills. I think it'll be really helpful for me in policy/community development work.
This course is useful for every FES student who plans on giving a presentation publicly or writing a professional email in the future:-)
Such skills are crucial in any profession. I have gained communication skills over the course of my career but I haven't had the opportunity to receive formal training.
It has made me better in communication. My career requires diplomatic stakeholder management and this course has enabled me to develop skills in communication

I am looking to go into environmental communications and this course is all about becoming a better communicator so it was probably the most relevant class I have taken so far at FES.I think everyone at FES should take this class even if they aren't going into the communications field because everyone still has to know how to present information and interact with others professionally no matter what field they end up going into.
Communication is key for all professionals

Environment communication fits in well with my interests of being a forest resources manager. This helped me to face some of my challenges in communicating with others and since the field am interested involves a lot advocacy I think its the perfect course for me.
Communications skills are critical in all professional activities. This course has helped me improve and elevate my skills, and I will continue to refine and practice these through other courses.
The course was very practical and helpful in improving my technical skills (eg.presentation skills, discussion and panel, networking etc).
Communication is vital for success in all careers. This course should be mandatory!
This class helps to fine-tune your communications skills - greatly needed and well done.
This is a great course for any environmental manager to take. Most students graduating from FES leave Yale without having strong communication skills - particularly public speaking.
These communication skills are invaluable for my future professional careers, I would recommend all students to take it, no matter what levels they are at.
See question 13- this course material is imperative to professional development.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: it was fun to watch my group get better at giving presentations etc through the class.
great feedback from your peers

Advantage was that it gave a good medium to reflect on communication skills and learn how to look for shortcomings (which better prepared me to recognize my own shortcomings).A main disadvantage was that we got most feedback from fellow group members; if there were group members who were too nice (or not paying enough attention) to provide substantive critiques, you didn't get as much useful help.
I enjoyed the small group format where we worked in the same group each week. It helped build trust and promote more open feedback.
It might be nice to change the group members for each exercise - otherwise, there's an element of comfort that makese the public speaking component less authentic

We all presented to each other in groups and gave each other feedback on our performance. It was useful to practice the skills discussed in the lecture component, and people's feedback was usually useful.
Peer feedback was wonderful

All of the classes had a group component to them. Communication skills take practice and it was very helpful to run through the different exercises. I also appreciated the smaller working groups because I get very nervous in front of large groups of people. It offered me the opportunity to practice on a smaller subset.
Colleague and instructors' feedback, and networking
Got good feedback and alternative views on techniques (i.e. what worked or didn't work for people in their own professional experiences). It was good practice speaking/presenting in front of people.
diverse feedback but not enough time to practice.
The work groups were good. Since the class is so big, its nice to get feedback on your skills in a smaller setting.
Good practice with peers. The constructive criticism we offered each other were very useful.
We learned a great deal from peer critiques. The class was broken into smaller 6-people groups that would then practice the skills of the day together.
We became practiced at giving each other feedback...but never had enough time to do so as fully as would have been nice.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: fill out the blue sheet as you go.
Don't be embarrassed! Be fearless and have fun. And speak slowly.

Take it seriously, and realize that you're taking the course to make yourself a stronger professional. As always, you get out what you put in; if you take the time to prepare and really work on the skills, you'll come out a much stronger communicator.
It's a great class and will be more relevant if you have a presentation for something else that you want to practice.
Take it!

To get the most out of it, spend time prepping your presentations. The class is work intensive, but take it no matter how busy your schedule is; you will learn something practical. Finally, USE what you learn here in your other classes, and in your work.
Ask the administration to make him cut the inappropriate comments BEFORE the class starts!
Make sure to find a few peers who are willing to give good constructive criticism, because this you will learn as much as you are challenged to learn in this class.
Participate fully in the activities because the benefitsare enormous and will remain with you forever.

Having assignments every week may seem like a pain, but they're totally worth it and will really help you in the long run. Take this class. It will definitely help you see what you need to work on, and help you become a more professional communicator.
Take the assignments seriously so the output is useful and relevant to your professional career
Take it and practice what you learn in class.
Take good notes and keep practicing!
Take the assignments seriously if you want to get the most out of them. IOW, spend sufficient time putting together decent presentations.
The more effort you invest in the exercises the more you will get from the course. Hard to do because the exercises feel a little artificial, but important nonetheless.
Prof. Vance is exceptional and is very helpful in guiding the students. Take it.
Prepare for each week by practicing your speeches. If you "wing" your pre-assignments, you won't get as muchout of this course.

This is a fantastic course! It really helpsyou learn the do's and dont's of writing emails, delivering a great presentation, speaking publicly, and so on. I HIGHLY recommend this professional skills course and you will come out of it with solid knowledge of how to communicate better.
Take it!!!! Try to really apply what you are learning to the presentations and activities. This will really help you gain something from the class. Focus on one or two things that you can improve.
Use the tips you learned in the lecture and really practiced it.

Practice makes perfect! Take every opportunity you have to apply the concepts learned in this class- other classes are a great opportunity to do this!Take good notes- you will need to refer back to them in the future.
Practice what you learn!
